Tic-Tac-Toe (X's and O's) is a simple game played on a 3Ã—3 grid.

Rules:

â€¢ Players take turns placing their mark (X or O) in empty squares.

â€¢ X plays first, followed by O.

â€¢ The goal is to form a row of three of your marks horizontally, vertically, or diagonally.

Connect 4 is a vertical game where pieces drop to the bottom of the board.

Rules:

â€¢ Players take turns dropping colored discs into a 7Ã—6 grid.

â€¢ The discs fall straight down to the lowest available position in the column.

â€¢ Red plays first, followed by Yellow.

â€¢ The goal is to connect four of your discs horizontally, vertically, or diagonally.

â€¢ The first player to connect four discs wins.

â€¢ If the grid fills up completely with no winner, the game is a draw.

Hex is a strategic connection game played on a hexagonal grid.

Rules:

â€¢ Players take turns placing stones of their color on the board.

â€¢ Red connects the top and bottom edges, while Blue connects the left and right edges.

â€¢ The goal is to create a continuous path connecting your two edges.

â€¢ Red plays first, followed by Blue.

â€¢ The first player to complete a path between their edges wins.

â€¢ There are no draws in Hex - someone always wins!

Havannah is a sophisticated connection game played on a hexagonal board. Players take turns placing stones on the hexagonal grid.

Rules:

â€¢ The game is played on a hexagonal board with 10 cells per side.

â€¢ Red plays first, followed by Blue.

â€¢ Once placed, pieces are never moved or removed.

â€¢ The goal is to create one of three winning structures:

1. A Ring: A loop that surrounds at least one cell (empty or not).

2. A Bridge: A connection between any two corner cells of the board.

3. A Fork: A connection between any three board edges (corners don't count as edges).

â€¢ The first player to create any of these structures wins.
